Answer: Your question follows a faulty line of thought. Technology is part of our evolution. For us to evolve a different way to have not had technology, we would not be what we consider human (or possibly even intelligent enough to ponder this question). Technology is part of a human, whether it’s the ability to create fire on-demand, or to build simple tools, or build weapons. Language, in a way, is also a sort of technology. Children are not born knowing how to recognize and understand, much less USE words. It is learned and used like any other technology. Perhaps not in the strictest terms, or byYour question follows a faulty line of thought. Technology is part of our evolution. For us to evolve a different way to have not had technology, we would not be what we consider human (or possibly even intelligent enough to ponder this question). Technology is part of a human, whether it’s the ability to create fire on-demand, or to build simple tools, or build weapons. Language, in a way, is also a sort of technology. Children are not born knowing how to recognize and understand, much less USE words. It is learned and used like any other technology. Perhaps not in the strictest terms, or by definition, but the difference is minimal at best. It may not be formed from science, but it is a tool we’ve developed to keep us ahead of the curve.
name: Franklin Veaux
question: https://www.quora.com/How-would-we-evolve-if-we-had-no-technology

Answer: Predicting the evolution of any species, is pretty much impossible, given how it depends a lot on the environment the species is in, the ecology of the other organisms around them, diet/predation, and the mobility of genes in the population.But, what we can do is imagine what the human ecological niche would be without technology.Without shelters, fire, and clothing we would be unable to live in cold regions like most of Europe, Russia, Most of North America, Argentina. We would be unable to survive in deserts. We would probably wind up in similar geographical regions to modern apes like chimpPredicting the evolution of any species, is pretty much impossible, given how it depends a lot on the environment the species is in, the ecology of the other organisms around them, diet/predation, and the mobility of genes in the population.But, what we can do is imagine what the human ecological niche would be without technology.Without shelters, fire, and clothing we would be unable to live in cold regions like most of Europe, Russia, Most of North America, Argentina. We would be unable to survive in deserts. We would probably wind up in similar geographical regions to modern apes like chimps, baboons, orangutans and geladas. And similar environments in the Americas. So, tropical to subtropical, near water.Without the ability to farm, cook, or cut up wild animals our diets would become very restrictive. And we would not be able to prey on large animals like cows. We would be eating lots of plants, fruits, nuts, bugs, small animals, maybe fish and rabbits, raw.All I can really guess, is that humans would evolve away from having pale skin, since that's a real handicap without clothing and shelter.And we would need better teeth, and we would probably get hairy. The food sources in the area would probably dictate our evolution.We might lose our long distance running endurance, since running down large prey is not much use if you can't spear it and cut it up.This thought experiment doesn't make much sense though, since tool use and pattern recognition is a key element of human brains, any population of humans without technology would begin to produce technologies straight away.

Answer: Technology can remove quite a few selective pressures and thus slow natural selection. For instance, medical technology (especially in the West) has eliminated or minimized quite a few childhood diseases, which was a huge part of natural selection among humans.However, the biggest effect, although indirect, that technology has had in slowing evolution is simply providing resources that allowed our population to get to over 7 billion.Large populations, of any species, only evolve slowly or not at all. This is called “stasis” and is the “stasis” part of Punctuated Equilibrium. Evolution dependsTechnology can remove quite a few selective pressures and thus slow natural selection. For instance, medical technology (especially in the West) has eliminated or minimized quite a few childhood diseases, which was a huge part of natural selection among humans.However, the biggest effect, although indirect, that technology has had in slowing evolution is simply providing resources that allowed our population to get to over 7 billion.Large populations, of any species, only evolve slowly or not at all. This is called “stasis” and is the “stasis” part of Punctuated Equilibrium. Evolution depends on new traits spreading toMost evolution occurs in small, geographically isolated populations facing new environments. Here again, technology has slowed the process. This time, it is transportation technology that means that populations are not isolated. There is gene flow between the small populations facing new environments, i.e. the Inuit, the Himalayan highlanders, Pacific islanders, etc. and other populations of humans.

Answer: Both chimps and macaques have entered the stone age already, routinely making and using crude stone tools. They are about where we (or, more accurately, our ancestors) were some 3.4 million years ago. The likelihood that we’ll allow another species to arise that could compete with us seems less than promising, but assuming we don’t kill them off, and that nothing else does, in about three and a half million years, there’s no reason it couldn’t happen.

Answer: Not likely, at least not within our era.There are a number of animals that seem to be able to attain levels of comprehension akin to human children but that seems to be the limit for animals like mountain gorillas, chimps, bonobos, dolphins, crows and maybe even some species of octopus.The thing is, most of the other great ape species that evolved either prior to us or in parallel with us are gone. In many cases they were probably in direct competition with us and we very likely wiped them out. There’s good evidence that this was the case with neanderthals.At this point homo sapiens have unlocNot likely, at least not within our era.There are a number of animals that seem to be able to attain levels of comprehension akin to human children but that seems to be the limit for animals like mountain gorillas, chimps, bonobos, dolphins, crows and maybe even some species of octopus.The thing is, most of the other great ape species that evolved either prior to us or in parallel with us are gone. In many cases they were probably in direct competition with us and we very likely wiped them out. There’s good evidence that this was the case with neanderthals.At this point homo sapiens have unlocked a kind of evolutionary cheat code that has allowed us to defy many of the normal constrictions of natural selection. We can can find edible foods in every climate, keep the weakest individuals in our ranks alive, traverse any geographical boundary and devise contraptions that make survival possible in just about any type of weather.There is little ecological space in which significant numbers of new species could take root, let alone flourish.

question: https://www.quora.com/How-would-we-evolve-if-we-had-no-technology

Answer: If it does, it will most likely be a bird, because birds have much denser, more compact brain tissue than we do (which is how a crow with a brain the size of a small almond can be as bright as a chimp with a brain the size of an orange), and the fact that they lay eggs means they don’t have to balance the advantages of a big brain against the disadvantages of either having a very wide pelvis or a high risk of death in childbirth.But even for birds, big brains have an energy cost, so they won’t evolve super-human intelligence unless it conveys a strong selection advantage. So you have to thinkIf it does, it will most likely be a bird, because birds have much denser, more compact brain tissue than we do (which is how a crow with a brain the size of a small almond can be as bright as a chimp with a brain the size of an orange), and the fact that they lay eggs means they don’t have to balance the advantages of a big brain against the disadvantages of either having a very wide pelvis or a high risk of death in childbirth.But even for birds, big brains have an energy cost, so they won’t evolve super-human intelligence unless it conveys a strong selection advantage. So you have to think of a reason why being super-intelligence would improve their reproductive success.

Answer: There’s no way to know what direction currently living species may evolve towards. That depends on a very large number of factors including environment (climate, predation, competition, etc.), natural and human-caused disasters, and many more. Because of this, it is more or less impossible to predict long-term speciation in any environment.Still, we can guess. The fact that humans evolved our incrThere’s no way to know what direction currently living species may evolve towards. That depends on a very large number of factors including environment (climate, predation, competition, etc.), natural and human-caused disasters, and many more. Because of this, it is more or less impossible to predict long-term speciation in any environment.Still, we can guess. The fact that humans evolved our increased brain size and intelligence so quickly implies that there’s no reason it couldn’t happen again. On the other hand, the very first single-celled life forms began nearly four BILLION years ago, and modern humans appeared only a couple hundred thousand years ago at most. In addition to that, advanced technology such as computers, air and space vehicles, etc. have barely existed for a century. This is less than the tiniest blink of a blink of a blink etc. of an eye in the history of life on earth. If it took this long for technology to appear, then it is possible that it may take a similar or greater amount of time for it to do so again.If that is indeed the case, there likely would not be...
